title: Standard of Practice for the MaxTwo System
text:
Welcome to our Tutorial Website
Here you will learn how to use the MaxWell System at the Electrophysiology Core Facility.

title: Standard of Practice for the MaxTwo System
text: Here you will learn how to use the MaxWell System at the Electrophysiology Core Facility.

title: Setup Recordings
text:
At this point, you should have done your first training with a staff member, so if possible refer to the specific recording strategies discussed in the training. This tutorial serves as a basic reminder of the most basic workflow, an activity scan and network assay.


At the beginning of your experimental journey, it might be difficult to evaluate whether you have biologically meaningful signal.



As a reminder, an activity scan assay is necessary to determine the most active areas of your chips. If your cells are not as active or still very young, you might need to perform an activity scan every single session. In general, it is recommended to lose a little bit of spatial resolution to gain more temporal resolution, especially if your cells are not very active.
Go to the Assay Tab and make sure to change the project to your specific project (IMPORTANT!!). Open a new Assay and choose Activity Scan. As a start, I would recommend to choose the Checker Board configuration and scan for at least 90s per configuration. This is a good compromise between temporal and spatial resolution. Of course, feel free to adjust the settings to your liking by either in- or decreasing the spatial resolution (e.g. Full Scan) or scanning time (sometimes, with highly connected mature neuronal networks, cells become active only in infrequent bursts, in which case the timing should be increased to 120-180s to avoid banding artifacts due to inactivity).
A whole Activity Assay might take up the majority of your session. If your cells are in a more matured state (typically after they start bursting) you might not need to repeat the Activity Assays every session and you could reuse the same map for several recordings.



A network assay records a specific configuration (typically the results of an Activity Assay) for a pre-defined period of time. Typically and depending on the activity of your cells, 5 to 10min are sufficient.
Here, you will typically need the result of an Activity Assay to choose the areas of interest to perform the Network Assay. Experiment with different configurations but stick to a specific one once you are happy with a type of configuration. We typically use Feature Maximization to always have the maximum number of electrodes (around 1020).
You can queue the Network Assay recording to take place right after your Activity Scan, just make sure that it is configured to take the newest Activity Scan results (which will appear black it is still running).



For pharmacological treatments, you might want to perform repeated measurements spaced out evenly. MaxWell does not support this out of the box but there is a work-around to still perform it in an unsupervised way. Please, still make sure that you book the corresponding time slots!


These are technically speaking not waiting blocks but they can be used as such. To configure one, choose a Record Assay and configure it to have a short record time (typically 1min). Then choose as an in-between cycle half of the wished waiting time (so, 30min for 1hr wait block), and repeat it for 3 cycles. Check on the “Estimate Time” button if the waiting block is correct.
IMPORTANT: Make sure you choose any configuration, a blank one will skip the waiting block. You can just click on “Choose Current Configuration”.
We can take advantage of the queuing of assays. By alternating Network Assays with Waiting Blocks (Record Assays), we can space out recordings and have repeated measurements. You will need to open new assays and start them in the order you want to have them run.

title: Setup Recordings
text:
Frequently Asked Questions

How do I know that my cells are fine?
This might be difficult to assess, since cells are not visible on the surface fo the sensors. We recommend to plate sister cultures in parallel on glass coverslips to have a general idea of the health of your cultures. In case of older cultures, you might start seeing a matt coating on the surface. If the media changes color to a more orange hue is also an indication that your cells are still metabolically active. Make sure, this is not due to a fungal or bacterial contamination which turns the media very quickly yellow with a cloudy layer on top of the sensor area. If this is the case, terminate the experiment immediately to avoid cross-contaminations, especially if you keep your cells in our cell culture facilities.


When can I expect neuronal activity in my cells?
This is highly dependent on your specific cells and even culturing conditions. Empirically, we start seeing neuronal activity from Day 14-18 for iPSC-derived neuronal cultures (with forward programming) and start of bursting activity from Day 18 up to 35. For primary neuronal cultures from rodents, activity starts much earlier from Day7 and start of bursting typically around Day 10-14. Your mileage may vary.

title: Access Remote Computer
text:
This is a short tutorial describing how to access and setup the MaxTwo System. You will need to have access to our remote Linux Computer and Cell Culture System as well as have excitable cells growing on 6- or 24-well MaxTwo plates.



Always make sure to book the system on EZBooking. If you don’t have access to the booking system, contact a staff member.
Turn on the MaxTwo recorder and gas mixer (located underneath the microscope on a small incubator).



Make sure to let the MaxTwo recorder warm up for 10-15min and the gas mixer to calibrate to 5% CO2. If it is not possible to come by sooner, you can ask a staff member to turn it on for you (some time in advance).





Click once on the blue button (touchscreen style, does not need much force)
Place the plate into the recorder, make sure the two notches on the upper short side aligns with the the holes on the plate.
Double-click on the blue button (alternatively, this can be done also from the software).
Close the recorder by clicking one time on the blue button.
If you have a 6-well plate, make sure to remember the unique ID of your plate.




In order to access the recording Linux Computer, you will need to have access to Citrix. There are several ZMB tutorials on how to do it for the first on Windows, Mac or Linux.
Click on “EPHAC MaxTwo VM” and connect to the PC via Remote Desktop (RDP). See below for troubleshooting if something goes wrong.
The username and password of the remote computer will be communicated to you separately.
Good to know:
If you are connected to the UZH intranet either directly or through VPN, you can also access the remote computer via RDP. This allows you to set custom resolutions for your display.



If you find the programs on from a previous user, make sure to close everything and start fresh every time. First, connect to the MaxTwo Recorder by clicking on “Server” on the Desktop, then open the MaxLab Live Program called “Scope”.
You will need to initiate the plate by clicking on “Initiate” (close to left bottom corner). If you own a 24-well plate, it will recognize the plate id automatically. Still make sure the plate id matches yours, as in rare instances it reports the previously recorded plate. If you own a 6-well plate, type in your ID.
Click on “Offset” and observe the Offset Histogram close to the right-upper corner becoming tighter.
Now you are ready to start a recording. Happy Spiking!!

title: Access Remote Computer
text:
Troubleshooting:

I cannot see the Citrix Icon of the Linux Computer:

Refresh Apps on Citrix (Wheel Cog Icon, upper right corner)
If problems persists, restart your computer and make sure you are on the newest Citrix version.
Try to connect to the browser version of Citrix.
Contact a staff member or the IT department of the ZMB.



The Linux Computer is very slow to respond or the display does not show the whole window:
This is a known issue with Macs and/or large monitor displays (4K monitors). Contact staff for workaround.


I got thrown out of the program and now it says that Number of Sessions have been reached:
Close down Citrix and wait 5mins before reconnecting. As an alternative, use RDP directly to connect to the Linux Computer, especially if this problem persists or repeats itself.


I cannot set the Offset or the Plate ID is wrong (24-well plate only):

Close MaxLab and Server connection, restart and reconnect.
If problem persists, reseat the plate in the MaxTwo Recorder.

This can be done from MaxLab. Click on the icon that looks like the MaxTwo recorder, then click on Unlock Plate and re-lock it. You might need to close and reopen the program one more time.
Alternatively, do it physically on the recorder by double-click on the button.

title: How to Seed Cells
text:
This is a very short tutorial on how you should handle the MaxWell plates and prepare them in order to seed your cells. Please, carefully read also the official MaxWell protocols. These are just our recommendations based on empirical data across many different project that we encountered at the facility.
There is no guarantee that it will work with these protocols and there might be some optimization steps necessary to find the right conditions for your cells.




If you own a 6-well plate, you will need to first pre-treat the plates and sterilize them. The pre-treatment with 1% Terg-a-zyme will make the surface of the sensor more hydrophilic. After preparing the 1% Terg-a-zyme in sterile ddH2O water, you can fill the chips and incubate it for 2-3 hours (up to over-night) at room temperature. Afterwards, you should thoroughly wash/rinse the plates with ddH2O (typically 3-4 times with 2-3ml).
For sterilization, spray down all other surfaces of the plate thoroughly with 70% EtOH, place your plates under a sterile environment (cell culture hood) and fill all wells and places around the wells with cell culture grade 70% EtOH. Make sure that the gold pins in at the bottom of the plates are as dry as possible as they corrode easily which will affect the recordings. Incubate the 70% for at least 30min under the hood (do not use UV-light as it can affect the longevity of the electronics).
Afterwards, rinse the plates with ddH2O 3-4 times and let it dry under the hood till first use.



MaxWell ships the 24-well plates already sterile, so you can directly continue with the pre-treatment steps. If you are re-using the plate (cell-free) you can perform the same steps as described above.




It is recommended to perform a pre-condition of the plates, especially before the first use. This is done by incubating the sterilized plates with sterile media in your incubator for 1-2 days. No need to perform a washing step before coating.



Before seeding your cells, the surface of the sensors need to be coated in order to provide a good surface for your cells to adhere. This is especially true for the surfaces of the HD-MEA sensors as they are smoother than typical cell-culture grade plastic-ware.
We always recommend to try the typical coating protocols that work with your type of cells, especially if you have experience seeding your cells on glass coverslips. If you normally don’t coat your surfaces before seeding your cells, we recommend as a starting point to coat the surfaces first with Poly-D (or L)-Lysine (PDL or PLL) overnight in an incubator, followed by a Laminin (20ng/uL) coating of 1-hr in the incubator before seeding your cells. Wash with ddH2O or PBS in-between steps.
In order to save Laminin solution, you can just coat the sensor area directly. Make sure to cover the whole area (~50uL). It is also recommended by many to not dry out the surfaces after coating.



After coating, your plates are ready to be seeded with cells. It is recommended to have a pilot experiment were different number of cells are seeded at different concentrations. Typically, we seed from 50’000-150’000 per well on the sensor area. The sensor area is covered by around 50uL of solution, so concentrate your cells accordingly. After seeding, place the plates back into the incubator for 1hr (no longer, as you risk to evaporate the 50uL), followed by carefully filling up the well (~500-600ul per well (24-well), 1-1.5ml per well (6-well)).
Proceed with normal cell culture routine.

title: How to Seed Cells
text:
Tipps and Tricks

NEVER touch the sensor area with any pipette tips, as you may risk to damage the electronics components. To aspirate any liquids, carefully place the aspirator on the corner of the sensor and slightly tilt the plate.



When placing 50uL of solution in the sensor area, make sure to dry out the immediate area around the sensor. Any liquid connection to wet spots outside the sensor area will result in your solution to spread and not fully cover your sensor area. Always make sure, you can see a bubble of liquid over the sensor area. This is crucial to a successful cell seeding as you risk to spread out your cells around instead of the sensor area.
